perturbation.contradicted_law: Florida's Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
perturbation.law_citation: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
perturbation.law_explanation: Although not explicitly codified as a statute with a specific notice period, Florida law implies a covenant of good faith and fair dealing in every contract. A five-day notice period for non-renewal could be argued as breaching this covenant if it's deemed unreasonably short and prejudicial, particularly if the other party has made significant investments or relies on the continuation of the contract. The shortened period creates a situation where one party could be unfairly surprised by non-renewal, especially when a 15-day notice is generally considered as a fair timeline for such purposes.

perturbation.contradicted_law: Florida's Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
perturbation.law_citation: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
perturbation.law_explanation: Under Florida law, every contract contains an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. This means that neither party can do anything that will injure the right of the other party to receive the benefits of the agreement. Reducing the termination notice period from 30 to 10 days, while technically permitted by the 'without cause' provision, could be deemed a breach of this implied covenant if it demonstrably harms one party because it doesn't give them reasonable time to make alternative arrangements or mitigate damages. The shorter notice period could be seen as acting in bad faith, especially if one party is significantly more reliant on the contract's continuation.
